title: CleanLaw podcast - Who Will Pay for Data Centers’ Massive Power Bills? It’s Probably You.
creators_list: Ari Peskoe (Harvard Law School), Eliza Martin (Harvard Law School)
description: This podcast episode, from Harvard University's Salata Institute for Climate and Sustainability's CleanLaw podcast, covers issues around energy use from data centers and their current growth trajectory. The podcast hosts cover the economics of data centers, the mechanics of utility electricity prices, infrastructure to support higher energy use, and the impact of data center construction and operation on the American public. The podcast frames this topic through a discussion of a recent paper on data centers and energy use. The podcast guest is skeptical of claims from utilities and data center companies and critical of the environmental and other impacts from data centers.
categories: Social Science: Environment and Resource Economics
citation: Peskoe, Ari, Eliza Martin. "CleanLaw podcast - Who Will Pay for Data Centers’ Massive Power Bills? It’s Probably You." 2025. Podcast. Indexed in the Project on Open and Evolving Metaliteracies, Carnegie Mellon University Libraries. DOI: . .

title: Submarine Cable Map
description: The Submarine Cable Map is a map tool that includes several data points about submarine data cable systems. It reveals the landing points of underwater cables, the status of planned cable systems, and information about which companies manage these systems. This resource is maintained by TeleGeography, a telecommunications data provider. While the mapping interface is freely accessible, the underlying data and code is only available if purchased.
citation: TeleGeography. "Submarine Cable Map." 1905. Map. Indexed in the Project on Open and Evolving Metaliteracies, Carnegie Mellon University Libraries. DOI: . CC BY-SA.

title: Chaos Creator Game
creators_list: Amanda Goodsett (Cleveland State University)
creator01_display: Amanda Goodsett (Cleveland State University)
description: Combating the spread of misinformation is a struggle that has inspired considerable research in the fields of psychology, education, political science, and information science, among others. Such research has found that “prebunking” or “inoculation” techniques — strategies that reduce the acceptance of misinformation before one has encountered it — have had marked success. One of the most successful prebunking interventions is the game “Bad News,” developed by Roozenbeek and van der Linden (2019). In the game, participants try to gain as many followers as possible on their social media platform. To do this, players engage in the strategies of misinformation-creators: they fabricate information, sow doubt about credible public figures and organizations, and promote belief in conspiracy theories, all of which increases engagement with the players’ posts. In the process, participants learn how misinformation is created and how appealing it can be, which raises their skepticism and improves their ability to identify misinformation. Chaos Creator is a modified version of the Bad News game. It incorporates the prebunking strategies of raising skepticism by describing common misinformation persuasion tactics. Students play the game in-person during a library information literacy instruction one-shot session.
learning_objective: Identify strategies used to spread misinformation online in order to avoid engaging with false or misleading messages. Assess the reliability of claims made by various sources in order to avoid engaging with false or misleading messages. Approach online claims with skepticism, while approaching information institutions (journalism, science, higher education) with measured trust.
categories: Studies in Human Society: Communications and Media Policy
citation: Goodsett, Amanda. "Chaos Creator Game." 2023. Game. Indexed in the Project on Open and Evolving Metaliteracies, Carnegie Mellon University Libraries. DOI: . CC BY-NC.

keywords_list: data creation and curation; prompting; equity
title: Intro to AI
description: This lesson consists of a very basic introduction to AI designed for youth ages 10-12. It walks them through an example of training data by "helping" a local Baltimore icon, Mr. Trashwheel, learn how to tell the difference between fish and trash. Examples can easily be swapped out for the local context that the lesson will be taught in. It then goes on to provide an activity about generating AI art. This opens the class up to conversations around ownership and feelings around what is being generated by the prompts supplied to AI.
learning_objective: Explain that AI is a computer that is trained on data given to it by humans. Explain that data can be incorrect or biased and that makes AI imperfect. Identify how AI can be used to assist in tasks that are tedious for humans. Apply what they have learned to an original idea, prompt, or problem.
keywords: data creation and curation; prompting; equity
categories: Information And Computing Sciences: Data Structures
citation: Higgins, Erin. "Intro to AI." 1905. Lesson Plan. Indexed in the Project on Open and Evolving Metaliteracies, Carnegie Mellon University Libraries. DOI: . CC BY-NC.

title: Demystifying Maps
description: Join a geography librarian on a maps show-and-tell. This video series features maps of different vintages, locations and purposes. We'll look at maps together and discuss what we see at first glance then focus in on details learning about different map elements along the way, such as scale, legends and symbology, latitude and longitude, milage charts, and publication information. Maps are fun to look at as we can explore not just different places, but different times in history as well. Some overall concepts we’ll cover across the series is that places change over time, as do map making techniques, but there are still commonalities and standards over time. Seeing lots of examples can also help those who make maps themselves - just as reading makes you a better writer. Another major point across the series is that maps are communication pieces, so like writing map makers need to know the map’s purpose and audience when choosing which information to include or exclude, and how to present it in a way that makes sense to the readers/users.
categories: Built Environment and Design: Visual Communication Design
citation: Miami University Libraries. "Demystifying Maps." 2024. Video. Indexed in the Project on Open and Evolving Metaliteracies, Carnegie Mellon University Libraries. DOI: https://www.doi.org/000000/00000000. .

title: Building Resilience to Misinformation: An Instructional Toolkit
creators_list: Justine Wheeler (University of Calgary)
creator01_display: Justine Wheeler (University of Calgary)
description: We created a toolkit for instructors to convey key ideas about misinformation to their students. The toolkit consists of five modules, which can be used individually or in combination: Introduction; The (Dis)Information Landscape; Identifying Misinformation; Interacting with Misinformation; and Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Misinformation
citation: Wheeler, Justine. "Building Resilience to Misinformation: An Instructional Toolkit." 2025. Lesson Plan. Indexed in the Project on Open and Evolving Metaliteracies, Carnegie Mellon University Libraries. DOI: . CC BY-NC.

title: Charting the New Frontier in Library Publishing: Using Janeway as an Open-Source Library Publishing Platform
creators_list: Dave Scherer, Daniel Evans, Rikk Mulligan
authors: Scherer, Dave; Evans, Daniel; Mulligan, Rikk
description: As the current institutional repository and publishing landscapes evolve, libraries must assess, adopt, and adapt the tools and platforms available to provide their library publishing services. Additionally, as options in both the vendor-hosted and open-source solution markets evolve and become available, library publishers should strike a balance between adopting and/or adapting solutions that will best meet the needs of their service models and communities efficiently and cost effectively. Beginning in 2017, Carnegie Mellon University began to transition its institutional repository service from Digital Commons to Figshare. Although the new repository service would expand features by also offering a data repository, this would leave Carnegie Mellon without a suitable publishing platform. While satisfied to use a hosted solution for its repository, the University Libraries wanted to diversify its dependence on vendor-hosted platforms by implementing an open-sourced publishing solution to be organizationally maintained by its new center for Digital Sciences, Humanities, Arts: Research and Publishing, dSHARP.
citation: Scherer, Dave, Daniel Evans. "Charting the New Frontier in Library Publishing: Using Janeway as an Open-Source Library Publishing Platform." 2018. Presentation. Indexed in the Project on Open and Evolving Metaliteracies, Carnegie Mellon University Libraries. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1184/R1/6294488.v1. CC BY.

title: Video Games and the Global South
description: Video Games and the Global South aims to redefine game culture from south to north, analyzing the cultural impact of video games, the growth of game development and the vitality of game cultures across Africa, the Middle East, Central and South America, the Indian subcontinent, Oceania and Asia.
citation: Penix-Tadsen, Phillip. "Video Games and the Global South." 2024. Book. Indexed in the Project on Open and Evolving Metaliteracies, Carnegie Mellon University Libraries. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1184/R1/8148680.v1. CC BY.
